document_type.purpose: To announce and regulate the collection of user fees on a section of National Highway 8B, superseding previous notifications and reflecting changes in road development and management.

summary.brief_summary: This document is a notification from the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways regarding the collection of user fees on National Highway 8B in Gujarat, specifically for the Jetpur-Gondal and Rajkot bypass sections. It outlines the fee structure, vehicle categories, and other relevant details for the collection of tolls by the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI).
summary.executive_summary: The notification details the implementation of user fees on a section of National Highway 8B in Gujarat, managed by the NHAI. The fees are applicable for the use of four or more lane sections, with different rates during and after the completion of six-laning. The document specifies the fee rates for various vehicle types, locations of toll plazas, and the calculation of fees for structures. It also includes provisions for monthly passes, discounts for local commercial vehicles, and penalties for overloaded vehicles. The estimated capital cost of the project is also mentioned.
summary.detailed_summary: This document, published in the Gazette of India, is a notification from the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways concerning the collection of user fees on National Highway 8B in Gujarat. The notification pertains to the sections from Km 117.00 to Km 143.00 (Jetpur-Gondal Section), and from Km. 175.00 to km. 185.00 (Rajkot bypass) of National Highway no. 8B. The Central Government, in exercise of powers conferred by the National Highways Act, 1956, authorizes the NHAI to collect fees. The fee structure is detailed in Table 1, specifying rates per kilometer for various vehicle types (cars, light vehicles, buses, trucks, and heavy machinery). Table 2 outlines the fee collection points (toll plazas) at Km 120.700 and Km 156.800, indicating the length for which fees are payable during and after the six-laning construction. Table 3 provides details of fees for structures (flyovers, bridges) with lengths exceeding 60 meters, converting their length into equivalent road length for fee calculation. The fee during construction is 75% of the base rate, and after completion of six-laning, it is 100%. The notification also includes provisions for monthly passes for local residents, multiple journey passes, discounts for commercial vehicles registered in the district, and penalties for overloaded vehicles. The document also mentions that the NHAI will maintain a record of the recovery of capital cost through user fees. The estimated capital cost of the project is Rupees 1815.81 crore.
key_points: The document is a notification regarding user fee collection on National Highway 8B in Gujarat.
The National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) is authorized to collect the fees.
Fee rates are specified for various vehicle types in Table 1.
Toll plazas are located at Km 120.700 and Km 156.800 (NH-27).
Fees are levied for structures (bridges, flyovers) exceeding 60 meters in length.
Provisions are made for monthly passes, multiple journey passes, and discounts for local commercial vehicles.
The estimated capital cost of the project is Rupees 1815.81 crore.
summary.audience: This document is intended for the general public, road users, and stakeholders involved in the management and operation of National Highway 8B, including the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI), contractors, and relevant government departments.

topics.topic_relationships: The topics are interconnected, with the notification establishing the legal basis for toll fees (Legal and Regulatory Framework), which are then detailed in terms of rates and structures (Fee Structure and Rates). These fees are applied to vehicles (Vehicle Categories and Exemptions) using the highway sections undergoing widening and construction (Highway Widening and Construction) as specified in the notification (National Highway 8B Toll Fee Notification).

document_structure.title: MINISTRY OF ROAD TRANSPORT AND HIGHWAYS NOTIFICATION
document_structure.content_summary: This notification from the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways concerns the collection of fees for the use of a section of National Highway 8B in Gujarat.

subsections.title: Table 1
subsections.content_summary: This table specifies the base rate of fees per km for different types of vehicles.

subsections.title: Table-2
subsections.content_summary: This table details the location of toll plazas and the length of road for which fees are payable during and after the construction period.

subsections.title: Table-3
subsections.content_summary: This table outlines the fees payable for the use of structures (bridges, flyovers) with lengths greater than 60m, converting their length into equivalent road length.

key_information.main_topic: Notification regarding the collection of fees for the use of National Highway 8B in Gujarat.
key_entities: Ministry of Road Transport and Highways
critical_facts_figures: Km. 0.00 to 143.00 and 160.00 to Km. 217.00 (Porbandar-Rajkot-Bamanbore Section)
Fee for commercial vehicle is 50% of the prescribed rate
action_items: NHAI to collect user fee as per the new notification.
Fees to be levied and collected at the specified rates at the Fee Plazas.
Monthly passes to be issued to local residents.
Passes for multiple journeys to be issued at specified rates.

document_metadata.author: Ministry of Road Transport and Highways

road_sections.context: entrusted the stretches from km 143.00 to km 160.00 (Gondal-Ribda section)
from Km. 0.00 to 143.00 and 160.00 to Km. 217.00 (Porbandar-Rajkot-Bamanbore Section)
widening of the existing stretch from Km. 117.00 to Km. 143.00 (Jetpur-Gondal Section)

summary.brief_summary: This table is a legal notification regarding the transfer of sections of National Highway 8B in Gujarat to the National Highways Authority of India and details planned road widening and improvement projects.
summary.detailed_summary: The notification references previous notifications related to the transfer of highway sections. It specifies the sections of National Highway 8B being transferred, including kilometer ranges. It also outlines plans for widening existing two-lane sections to four lanes and improving existing four-lane sections, with the projects to be undertaken on a BOT (Toll) basis. The notification mentions specific sections like Jetpur-Gondal, Rajkot bypass, and Gondal-Rajkot sections.
key_observations: Sections of National Highway 8B are being transferred to the National Highways Authority of India.
Road widening and improvement projects are planned for specific sections of the highway.
The projects will be undertaken on a BOT (Toll) basis.
Specific kilometer ranges and section names are provided for the projects.
The notification references previous government notifications related to the highway.
summary.data_range: Specific sections of National Highway 8B in Gujarat, India, with kilometer ranges and project details.
summary.audience: Government officials, infrastructure developers, legal professionals, and anyone involved in or affected by the highway projects.

key_insights: The government is actively transferring and developing highway infrastructure.
The BOT model is being used for highway projects, indicating a public-private partnership.
Specific sections of the highway are targeted for improvement, suggesting a strategic approach.
The notification provides legal clarity and official sanction for the projects.
The project aims to improve connectivity and potentially reduce travel times.
insights.trends: The trend is towards infrastructure development and improvement of national highways.
insights.anomalies: No obvious anomalies are present in the provided text.
insights.comparisons: The notification implicitly compares the existing road conditions with the planned improvements.
insights.data_quality_issues: The text is a legal notification and appears to be complete. No data quality issues are apparent.

table_type.purpose: To announce the transfer of sections of National Highway 8B to the National Highways Authority of India and outline planned improvements.
table_type.data_category: Infrastructure projects, legal notifications, highway sections

chunks.content: MINISTRY OF ROAD TRANSPORT AND HIGHWAYS NOTIFICATION New Delhi, the 11th March, 2025 S.O. 1132(E).—Whereas by notification of the Government of India in the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways number S.O. 1192(E) dt. 03/12/2001 and number S.O. 465 (E) dated the 26th April, 2002 issued under Section 11 of the National Highway Authority of India Act 1988 (68 of 1988), the Central Government has entrusted the stretches from km 143.00 to km 160.00 (Gondal-Ribda section) and from Km. 0.00 to 143.00 and 160.00 to Km. 217.00 (Porbandar-Rajkot-Bamanbore Section) of National Highway no. 8B respectively in the State of Gujarat to the National Highways Authority of India referred to as the “Authority”); And whereas, the Authority was entered into an agreement with West Gujarat Expressway Limited, having its registered office at The IL&FS Financial Centre, Plot C-22, G-Block, Bandra Kurla Complex, Bandra East, Mumbai-400051 (hereinafter referred to as the “Concessionaire”) for widening of the

summary.brief_summary: This chart details toll fees for highway sections, including rates during and after construction, and fees related to structures. It provides a breakdown of fee structures based on location and type of structure.
summary.detailed_summary: The chart presents toll fee structures for two toll plazas, outlining fees during the construction phase and after the completion of six-laning. It includes information on the length of the fee-paying sections, the applicable rates, and the treatment of structures exceeding 60 meters in length. Additionally, it provides details on specific structures, including their type and length, and how these lengths are converted into equivalent road lengths for fee calculation.
key_observations: Toll fees are location-specific, varying between the two toll plazas.
Fee rates change after the completion of six-laning.
Structures longer than 60m are subject to additional fees, calculated based on an equalization factor.
The chart provides details on specific structures like flyovers and bridges, including their lengths.
The fee structure includes a provision for 75% of the base rates during construction and 100% after completion.
summary.data_range: The data covers toll fees for specific locations (chainage) on a highway, including details on structures and their lengths.
summary.audience: Government agencies, highway construction companies, toll operators, and financial analysts.
summary.purpose: To provide a clear and detailed breakdown of toll fee structures for a specific highway project, likely for regulatory, financial, or operational purposes.

trends: Fee rates increase after the completion of six-laning.
The inclusion of structures leads to higher fees.
The fee structure is designed to be dynamic, changing based on project milestones.
patterns: A clear pattern of higher fees post-construction.
A consistent method for calculating structure-related fees.
trends.outliers: None apparent in the provided data.
correlations: Positive correlation between the length of structures and the equivalent road length used for fee calculation.
Positive correlation between the completion of six-laning and increased fee rates.
trends.growth_rates: Not applicable, as the data represents a static fee structure at different stages.
trends.statistical_significance: Not applicable, as the data is not presented in a way that allows for statistical analysis.

key_insights: Toll fees are dynamic, changing based on the stage of construction.
Structures significantly impact the toll fee calculation.
The fee structure is designed to incentivize the completion of the six-laning project.
The chart provides a clear methodology for calculating fees based on structure lengths.
The data suggests a phased approach to toll collection, with different rates during and after construction.
insights.business_implications: The fee structure directly impacts the financial viability of the highway project and the revenue generated by toll collection. Understanding the fee structure is crucial for financial planning, investment decisions, and operational management.
insights.recommendations: Conduct regular audits to ensure accurate fee collection based on the defined structure. Analyze the impact of structure-related fees on overall revenue. Monitor the progress of the six-laning project to anticipate changes in fee rates.
insights.limitations: The chart does not provide information on the base rates mentioned in Table 1, which are essential for calculating the actual fees. The data is specific to the two toll plazas mentioned and may not be representative of other highway projects.
insights.comparative_analysis: The chart allows for a comparison of fee rates before and after the completion of six-laning. It also enables a comparison of fees based on the location of the toll plaza and the presence of structures.

Each vehicle type is associated with a specific numerical value, presumably representing a fee or charge. The values increase with the size and complexity of the vehicle, suggesting a tiered pricing system.
key_observations: The table categorizes vehicles based on size and axle count.
Fees increase with vehicle size and axle count.
The fee for oversized vehicles is the highest.
The table likely represents a fee schedule for road usage or permits.
summary.audience: Government agencies, transportation authorities, and commercial vehicle operators.

key_insights: The fee structure is directly related to the size and weight of the vehicle.
There is a clear progression in fees as vehicle size increases.
The table suggests a system designed to manage and potentially regulate commercial vehicle traffic.
The fee structure could be used to generate revenue or to incentivize the use of smaller vehicles.
trends: A positive correlation between vehicle size/axle count and the associated fee.
comparisons: The fee for a Light Commercial Vehicle is significantly lower than that for Oversized Vehicles.

summary.brief_summary: This chart details toll fees for specific locations along NH-27 in Gujarat, differentiating between the construction period and after the completion of six-laning.
summary.detailed_summary: The chart presents toll plaza locations, the length of road for which fees are applicable, and the corresponding fee rates. It compares the fee structure during the construction phase with the structure after the road is expanded to six lanes. The chart also includes information on structures with lengths exceeding 60 meters and their impact on toll calculations. The data is presented for two specific locations along NH-27.
key_observations: Toll rates are based on the base rates mentioned in Table 1.
The fee structure changes after the completion of six-laning.
Structures longer than 60m are considered separately for toll calculation.
The chart provides data for two toll plaza locations.
During construction, the fee is 75% of the base rate.
summary.data_range: Toll fees and structure information for specific locations on NH-27 in Gujarat, covering both the construction period and the post six-laning completion phase.
summary.audience: Government agencies, road construction companies, toll operators, and transportation analysts.
summary.purpose: To provide a clear overview of the toll fee structure for specific locations on NH-27, including changes associated with road expansion and the treatment of long structures.

trends: Toll rates increase after the completion of six-laning.
The fee structure is consistent across the two locations, with the exception of the location-specific chainage.
patterns: A pattern of reduced fees during the construction phase followed by an increase after the road is expanded.
outliers: No obvious outliers are present in the provided data.
correlations: There is a correlation between the completion of six-laning and an increase in toll rates.
growth_rates: The growth rate of toll fees is positive after the completion of six-laning.
trends.statistical_significance: The observed patterns appear to be statistically significant, given the clear distinction in fee structures between the construction and post-construction phases.

key_insights: Toll rates are reduced during the construction phase.
The completion of six-laning leads to a change in the toll fee structure.

insights.business_implications: Road construction companies and toll operators need to understand the fee structure to estimate revenue and plan for infrastructure investments. summary.brief_summary: This table outlines the fee structure at a toll plaza (Km 156.800 on NH-8E) during the construction phase and after the completion of six-laning, detailing the rate at which fees are payable based on equivalent road length.
summary.detailed_summary: The table presents a comparison of fee calculation methods before and after the six-laning project. During construction, the fee is based on 75% of the base rates mentioned in Table 1, applied to an equivalent road length. After completion of six-laning, the fee is 100% of the base rates for four or more lanes, also based on equivalent road length. The table specifies the equivalent road length calculation for the construction phase.
key_observations: The fee structure changes significantly after the completion of six-laning.
The fee during construction is a percentage of the base rate.
The fee after six-laning is 100% of the base rate.
The equivalent road length is a key factor in determining the fee.
The table refers to a 'Table 1' for base rates, which is not included in the provided context.

For the purposes of this rule, any provisional completion of the project shall not be treated as completion of the project. 4. It specifies the 'From Km' and 'To Km' chainage, indicating the start and end points of each structure. The table also provides the length of each structure in kilometers and calculates the total length of structures exceeding 60 meters.

The structures include flyovers, elevated structures, and major bridges.
The lengths of the structures vary significantly, from 0.08085 km to 1.100 km.
The total length of structures greater than 60m is 2.21285 km.
The chainage values indicate the location of the structures along a route.
